clinical_study.brief_title: Physical Activity Levels in COVID-19 Patients Admitted to Intensive Care
clinical_study.official_title: Physical Activity Levels in COVID-19 Patients Admitted to Intensive Care Requiring Invasive Ventilation: An Observational Study

lead_sponsor.agency: University Hospital Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: University Hospital Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: This is an observational study exploring the levels of mobility and rehabilitation in patients admitted to critical care with a confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19

detailed_description.textblock: An admission to an intensive care unit (ICU) often results in significant muscle weakness and physical deconditioning, which can take many months or even years for recovery. Early and progressive programmes of rehabilitation are recommended to limit any muscle loss and support recovery as early as possible. Patients admitted to intensive care with COVID-19 have been found to require prolonged periods of mechanical ventilation, high sedation and neuromuscular blocking use and as a result require prolonged stays in the ICU. As yet no data exists to examine the specific physical impact this may have, or whether it is safe and feasible to commence this earlier rehabilitation within the ICU for patients with a diagnosis of COVID-19. Our study set out to evaluate the levels of rehabilitation which were delivered in a large acute NHS trust.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At ICU discharge, an average of 3 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Highest level of mobility achieved at the point of ICU discharge

primary_outcome.time_frame: during ICU admission, up to 3 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Time taken to first mobilise, defined as sitting on the edge of the bed or higher

secondary_outcome.description: Discharged to home, home with rehab, or a community rehab facility

arm_group.description: Observations taken of standard physiotherapy practice. All patients are assessed daily and receive respiratory care and rehabilitation as deemed appropriate by the treating therapist

intervention.description: Daily physiotherapy to include respiratory care and rehabilitation based on the individual therapists clinical reasoning

study_pop.textblock: Adults admitted to ICU with a confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19, mechanically ventilated for >24 hours and surviving to ICU discharge were included.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- having a confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19
- being mechanically ventilated for at least 24 hours
- surviving to critical care discharge.
Exclusion Criteria:
- none
